references:
Among variants of all kinds, the Paillier (Paillier, 1999), FV (Fan and
Vercauteren, 2012) and CKKS (Cheon
et al., 2017) schemes are the most prevalent ones. The Paillier scheme allows additions to be performed on encrypted data, while the FV and CKKS schemes permit both additions and multiplications on ciphertexts. The Paillier and FV schemes take integers as plaintexts, while the CKKS scheme can encrypt real or complex numbers but yields only approximate results. They are supported by many general-purpose cryptographic libraries (Paillier, 1999; sea, 2021; pal, 2021; hel, 2021; hea, 2021) for their satisfaction of semantic security (Shafi and Silvio, 1982), as well as relatively better efficiency compared to other alternatives. Table 1 briefly summarizes the three schemes.

references: Performance overhead    Yet, these three schemes are not best suited to cross-silo FL environment due to their substantial overhead in the absolute sense. To illustrate, we benchmark the ciphertext size, encryption time, decryption time, and addition time (that corresponds to performing addition evaluation over 10 ciphertexts) of the three schemes, with various plaintext sizes (we defer the detailed settings of their security parameters in Section 5.4). As Paillier and FV cannot take FPNs as inputs, we feed them with quantized numbers, each of which is a 16-bit integer (we elaborate on the quantization details in Section 5.2). Table 2 (grey rows) reports the results observed on a c5.4xlarge Amazon EC2 instance (16 vCPUs and 32 GB memory), wherein we make three main findings as follows.

So far, batch encryption is the state-of-the-art optimization direction for accelerating general HE schemes. Basically, it allows both en-/decryption and homomorphic evaluation to be performed on multiple plaintexts in a data-parallel manner. As for Paillier, this can be achieved by concatenating multiple plaintexts into a large-yet-legitimate one (Liu
et al., 2019; Zhang
et al., 2020). In terms of FV and CKKS, more advanced methods such as CRT-based encoding technique can be applied (Smart and
Vercauteren, 2010, 2014). For each of the three schemes, we compare the fully batched version against the plain version. As shown in Table 2 (white rows), batch encryption has significantly reduced the computational cost for all three schemes.

Substantial message inflation   Still, the message inflation factor remains suboptimal even with the aid of batch encryption. As shown in Table 2 (white rows), compared to the plaintext size, the ciphertext size in Paillier, FV, and CKKS are expanded by 2.4×2.4\times–42.2×42.2\times, respectively. These observations also comply with the observations in the literature (Damgård
et al., 2010; Fauzi, 2012; Cho
et al., 2020). Such a degree of message inflation can cause salient communication overhead in cross-silo FL, where participating organizations typically do not share a data center and have to communicate atop wide-area networks (WANs). To briefly quantify the shortage of WAN bandwidth, we measure the network bandwidth between all pairs of five sites in different regions (London, Tokyo, Ohio, N. California, and Sydney). For each ordered pair of regions (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B), we use iperf3 (ipe, 2021) to time packet sending from A𝐴A to B𝐵B for five rounds and estimate the average bandwidth.

Figure 8 further visualizes the communication improvement in terms of traffic volume. Compared to batch optimization version of Paillier, FV, and CKKS, FLASHE consistently brings down around 2.1×\times-42.4×\times of network footprint. This adheres to the ciphertext size gap observed in our offline HE benchmark results (yellow rows in Table 2), where the ciphertext of FLASHE is 2.4×\times–42.2×\times smaller than that of the three baselines. To sum up, the intrinsic complexity of general HE schemes prevents batch encryption from further unleashing their efficiency potential. FLASHE, on the other hand, is constantly lighter in both computation and communication due to the exemption of asymmetricity and versatility.

To dive deeper, as for (1), we notice that such encryption overhead is significantly less than that observed from our HE benchmark results (yellow rows in Table 2). This can be mainly explained by the latency hiding impact of mask precomputation (§ 5.3), and we provide more empirical evidence of its effectiveness in Section 6.6. In terms of (2), by referring to Figure 8, we can see that FLASHE does not incur any network inflation for all applications. These are not accidental results as vanilla FLASHE by design does not inflate the message size at all. In other words, although the communication is left to be a performance bottleneck of FLASHE, it is already highly optimized in the absolute sense. We thus conclude that FLASHE exhibits near-optimality in both computation and communication.

We next examine FLASHE’s compatibility with top s𝑠s% sparsification. Without loss of generality, we set s𝑠s to 10%, i.e., 90% of the uplink traffic is removed. To reduce the number of extreme model update values being delayed (Lin
et al., 2018), we rise the sparsity every 10 rounds as follows: 20%, 60%, 80%, 90% (exponentially increase till 90% and then stay stable). The corresponding convergence behaviors are given in Figure 9 (purple lines) for readers’ reference666We do not further fine-tune the sparsity scheduling as we are only interested in per-round computation and communication overhead.. As indicated in Table 2 (grey rows), applying general HEs can counteract the performance benefits brought by sparsification due to their prohibitively high overhead without batch optimization. We here only include Paillier as our baseline since FV and CKKS are too expensive to be feasible. We measure the same metrics as in Section 6.2 when the sparsity gets stable and reports the results in Figure 10 and Figure 11.

references: Denoting by N𝑁N the total number of clients and by D𝐷D the length of a plaintext vector, we summarize the cost of vanilla FLASHE as in Table 3. Essentially, the communication and addition cost is exactly the same as those in the case when data is sending in the clear. As for encryption, as the time and space complexity of computing a PRF is constant, the computation and storage cost for each client performing encryption is only proportional to the message size, which is the minimum asymptotic cost no matter what homomorphic encryption scheme is chosen.

references: We next investigate the end-to-end monetary benefits by training the three models till convergence. As this can take exceedingly long time and high cost in real deployment, which is beyond our cloud budget, we instead project the per-round profiling results (§ 6.2) into a whole training span. To that end, we additionally need the round-to-convergence information which can be obtained by local FL simulation with the same precision (i.e., by employing 16-bit quantization). As measured, for ResNet-20, the training reaches the peak accuracy 72.0% at the 374thth{}^{\text{th}} epoch, while GRU and CNN ends up with 57.7% accuracy at the 95thth{}^{\text{th}} epoch, and 88.4% accuracy at the 277thth{}^{\text{th}} epoch, respectively. We depict the learning curves at Figure 9 (yellow lines). We refer to the AWS pricing scheme in accounting without loss of generality, and calculate the total cost of all clients, the cost of the server, and the overall cost of the three FL tasks, as listed in Table 4.

We first notice that the cost of FLASHE is still close-to-optimal in the economic sense. Specifically, FLASHE is merely 1%–5% more expensive than plaintext training in terms of the total cost (the grey column in Table 4). When FLASHE is compared against the batch optimization version of the baseline HEs, its expense is consistently lower, with 26%–73% cost reduced against Paillier++Batching, and 49%–89% and 69%–94% against FV++Batching and CKKS++Batching, respectively. This also indicates that the cost benefits can be more salient as the model grows larger. In all, FLASHE is a cost-saving privacy-preserving solution in cross-silo FL.
